titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. My eye very much inflamed, but as yet my studious resolution is inflexible.— Made out my account for the Secretary of State, and sent it off. Took my second lesson of Italian. The language I think is not difficult to learn. Took a walk afterwards with Bielfeld. Rest of the day as usual.

2. Received Letters from the Secretary of the Treasury (duplicates) and one from Messrs: Condy and Co: of Charlestown. Wrote part of a letter to the Secretary of State. Met Bielfeld walking in the wood. At the
play in the Evening. Oberon king of the Fairies. A German Opera compiled from a Poem of Wieland. The second poem says Bielfeld, in that language at least in reputation. Klopstock’s Messiah is the first. The German Literature is highly interesting. If I can find time I must learn the language. At present two upon my hands at once is sufficient.— Met Souque there too. More of his literary pretensions. Walk with Bielfeld in the Voorhout after the play.

3. Third lesson of Italian. From the distribution of my time I find myself now always in a hurry. I shall be under the necessity of making some alteration.— Short walk before dinner. Long one in the Evening.

4. Anniversary of Independence. My brother in celebration of the day devoted it to amusement.— I passed it as usual.— Called to see Mlle: Lorenzi who was not at home— Attended the debates in the National Assembly. Saw Reuterswerd there.— Drew up a Note to present to the President of the Assembly.

5. Called this morning to see Mr: Van Leyden, the Secretary of the Committee of foreign Affairs, to enquire of him in what manner official papers are to be addressed under the present Government. He said they might be addressed to the President of the Assembly, who as such is also President of the Committee, and would lay the application before the one or the other according as the subject should render it proper. Told him my object was to obtain answers to two memorials, heretofore presented to the States General. Upon that respecting the Wilmington Packet he said he had no information. As to that concerning the appointment of Consuls, he recollected that the memorial was taken ad Referendum by the States of Holland. That he remembered an observation at the time was made by some of the members that the Colonies could not be considered as a constituent part of the Republic, and the article of the Treaty did not therefore perhaps apply to them.— But he did not know whether this would be the answer.— Mentioned his having seen me yesterday in the Gallery of the Assembly.— Spoke of a report made some days ago by the Representative Lüblin upon the subject of separating the affairs of the Church from those of the State. The reporter is a man of literary reputation, and has translated Young’s night-thoughts into Dutch.— Van Leyden, is a mild, pleasant; modest man.— Such men are much more comfortable to treat with but very often not more easy, than harsher characters.— Was to have taken a lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s lodgings, but he has just changed, and I could not find him out. As I was going out met M: Du Roure, who was coming to see me. He called on me this afternoon to enquire whether the Government of the United States had taken any Official steps in behalf of Mr: De la Fayette. told him that not having had any communications from the Government on the subject I could not say.— Walk in the Evening.

6. Went this morning, and presented a Note to the President of the National Assembly. (Hartogh.) met in the antichamber an old acquaintance Mr: Van Lynden. Who is now Minister from this Republic to the Court of Denmark. Accosted him, and mentioned my having formerly known him. But he did not remember me. Enquired however after my father. They were diplomatic brethren at London, from whence de Lynden was dismissed, after the Revolution of 1787. and has had a political resurrection since the last Revolution— When I delivered my note to the President he told me that I should have an answer as soon possible. Was received with great and formal civility. Bielfeld called on me. Took a walk with him, and afterwards at his lodgings took a lesson of Italian. Weather rainy and cold the principal part of the day. Walk in the evening.

7. Attended the debates in the National Assembly, a short time. They soon adjourned. Heard an appel nominal, on a question which excited the party spirit—on the first trial the votes were equal. On the second the violent party had a majority of one vote.— Usual mixture of reading & writing.

8. Weather cold and rainy for many days past. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s lodgings.— Mr Bourne writes my brother that he is informed Mr: King is appointed Minister to Great-Britain, and Coll: Humphreys to Spain, and that Mr: Gore is arrived in England.— Wrote a little. Finished this morning Luzac’s Richesse de la Hollande. If the merit of any performance is proportioned to the tediousness of going through it, I may be proud of having read this book through. The author was among other things a bookseller, and his great object must have been to make a great book of small materials. His information is a grain of wheat in a bushel of chaff.

div.p: 9. Began this morning the Traité General du Commerce by Ricard. 2. Vols: 4to: He begins with the Commerce of the United Provinces, and is much more clear and satisfactory than Luzac.— Received a letter from Louisa. Set to answer it immediately.— Visit from Mr: Thomas Fulton, a North Carolinian, who came from Philadelphia the 20th: of May. He arrived at Hamburg, and goes on this Evening towards Paris.— Has dispatches and many private letters for Mr: Monroe. None for me.— Confirms the news Mr: Bourne wrote my brother. Finished Pitt’s Eneid this afternoon. Dr: Johnson’s opinion of it in comparison with Dryden’s, upon the whole is just. But it is a Justice friendly to Dryden. He might have been rather more liberal to Pitt without injustice.— At the German Play in the Evening. A new Opera the Spiegelritter—or Knight of the Mirror. Duller than usual. I did not even admire the music.

10. Packet of letters this morning under cover from Mr: Johnson principally from America. 20th: of May: but very little upon the public affairs. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. It bears very hard upon my time, and yet I know not what part of my employment to give up.— Finished Began upon Rowe’s translation of Lucan’s Pharsalia. I have heretofore looked occasionally into the original, but never read it through. The translation is altogether new to me.— Weather continues so cold and rainy that I can scarce snatch a dry moment for walk. Employed part of this Evening however to the purpose.

11. I enter this day upon my thirtieth year. The periodical days of reflection are seldom satisfactory to me. The principal reproach my conscience can make me for the last year, is too much time spent in relaxation, perhaps lost. Let me strive to make a better improvement of the next. My apology for the past must be the state of my health. Though insufficient it is the best I have. The irresistible dissipation of London is none. The weakness of the heart—is only a plea for mercy.— Much more might have been done by me. Of positive wrongs I feel very clear during the last year. None of its predecessors for a long time have been so innocent. Yet none of them have been more exposed to temptation.— Visit this morning from Captain Willard and Mr: Lemonnier. gave them Passports for Paris. Letter from D. Sargent. June 7.— Letter from J. & C. Halbach. more troubles of theirs. Called on Mr: Noël. He is gone down to the Texel. Mr: Mersen.
Finished reading the Memoirs of Dumouriez this afternoon, and read some pages in those of Garat. The great characteristic trait of Dumouriez is ambitious vanity. It is the common feature of almost every eminent political character which the french Revolution has produced. There appears about him great ability in the military line, a great facility at repartee and address in conversation, but miserable ignorance and folly upon the subject of Government. His style is rapid, but not precise, his manner of relating, attractive in the highest degree, but with a colouring to his own advantage, for which allowances are to be made. He professes a great love for his Country and a strong sense of humanity; but in both cases it is evidently the result of a sentiment and not of a Principle. He loves his Country because the People at times shew attachment to him. He detests proscriptions, because he was proscribed, and indeed if you look through his book for a moral principle as the guide of his actions, you will find abundant proof that he had none. His first ambition is to be a monk, and six months after he is willing to be any thing on earth but monk. He attempts a suicide in the rage of a momentary obstacle in his love, and repents just in time to save his life. He offers to serve the Genoese against Corsica, and the Corsicans against Genoa. He forms a plan to conquer Corsica by the breach of a Treaty, and quarrels with the Minister who refuses to execute this plan. He declares his aversion upon principle to duelling in relating an attempt to force a man to fight a duel with him, which was prevented only by the base submission of his antagonist. He relates every thing that happened to him at the Bastille, and adds that on coming out of it he had a formal oath administered to him never to reveal any thing that he had witnessed there; while to shew that it is not inconsistency with which he is chargeable, he tells us that he considered the oath as a mere formality, binding him to nothing. He affects a regard for La Fayette, for Rolland, and for several others whom at the same time he endeavours by every part of his narration concerning them to ruin in reputation. In short there is scarce a page of his book but proves a deficiency of principle, and an overruling vanity, in a mind very vigorous and active.

12. After the lesson of Italian, had but time to take one turn in the Voorhout. Walk in the Evening. On my return home found letters from Hall, and from Mr: Gore with one likewise from America. and Newspapers and reviews. Read only the letters however this Evening.

13. Mr: Noël returned home last Evening. Called on him this forenoon. Mr: Van Leyden was with him— Waited a short time. Conversation on the subject of a Passport for the arms to be exported to America by the house of Halbach & sons. He told me he would give one, but must have, the permission granted by the States General and the account of the merchants or certified copies of them to serve for his justification.— Walk this Evening in the Voorhout. Weather very chilly and unpleasant, with rain.

14. Sent Mr: Noël his papers with a request for the Passport, which he soon after accordingly sent me. Visit from Mr: Bonnechose requesting a certificate that he resides in America. He
He says he has been there 15 months and means to return there again, so that there can be no question but that he resides there.— Told him I could give him no such certificate; and felt almost indignant, that he should ask one— Agreed to give him a certificate of what he declared, adding that I believe it true. He thought that would not serve his turn but I positively refused to give him any other, and he is therefore to take that.

Not up this morning till after six. Find it difficult to settle the precise moment of rising, with constant regularity.— Hurry myself too, by undertaking too much.— Finished reading the Memoirs of Garat. A very interesting thing, full of details concerning some of the individuals and parties that have figured in the french Revolution.— This I think completes my perusal of all the important publications by the actors of those scenes, and Garat’s book is superior to all the others

15. Rose before 5. to atone for yesterday’s deficiency. Visit from Mr: Bonnechose, and gave him his certificate. Requested him however not to make me any longer the vehicle of correspondence from England, informing I should receive no more letters for Mr: Mouchon American Merchant; he said those letters were not for him, but for one of his friends whom he expected here shortly. I told him whoever they were for I was not disposed to receive any more of them. Lesson of Italian, and a short tour in the Voorhout. Long walk in the Evening. Began reading Pratt’s gleanings.

16. Not up again till a quarter after six. Begin to be apprehensive for my perseverance in early rising. My whole arrangement of business &c affected by it for the day. Long Evening walk in the Voorhout. Reuterswerd and Bielfeld. the latter much pleased with Garat. Another visit this forenoon from Mr: Bonnechose. It seems he opens his friend Mouchon’s letters, and though he told me yesterday they were not for him he did not hesitate to shew me one of them to day which proved the contrary. I shall have as little to do with them as possible, and with him too.

17. Up sometime before 5 again by way of atonement. Weather at length has got to be tolerably moderate— Lesson of Italian and walk in the Voorhout, with Bielfeld. My brother went with Mr: M’Queen to Delft. Long walk in the Evening. Visit before dinner from Mr: Treat who is going in a day or two to England.

18. Up a second time before five; which completes my expiation for the slight failure of Saturday. Visit this forenoon from Mr: Tuckerman, who is going to England. Has been waiting almost three weeks for a wind. My writing hours too much appropriated to translations. I scarce write any more than I did in England. Several letters remain unanswered— Walk before dinner. Long one in the wood this Evening. Met Bielfeld in the Voorhout. Intended to have paid a visit. Life become too sedentary.

19. Returned to my hour of rising, just before six. But with readings and translations. Dutch and Italian the hours waste away.— Very short letter to Mr: Monroe.— Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. Mr: Levsen called while we were at it.— Walk with them in the wood.— Evening walk alone.

Finished reading Rowe’s translation of the Pharsalia. Dr: Johnson says it is not esteemed so much as it is worth, and it will please more, the better it is known. I have never read it before, and have been gratified in the perusal. I have occasionally compared it with the original, and find that the translator has added near an hundred lines at the end of the tenth book to close the action. It is not an epic poem. Nor is it a fair criticism to compare it with the Eneid. It has certainly much more originality, and the characters are much more striking than those of Virgil. The sentiment and language are sometimes turgid and sometimes sublime. There is not much diversity of incident; but after Homer who can undertake to invent? Virgil generally copies, but what Lucan gives is all his own. He has more sentiment and philosophy, than is usual in Poems of such length. Much more than Homer in the Odyssey. But his great delight seems to be the description of things terrible. The cutting down of the sacred wood, the troops in a vessel of Caesar’s party, who by consent destroy one another to avoid falling into the hands of the Enemy, the scene of Caesar embarking in the night in a small barque, and the storm that he weathers in it; the sorceress Erictho, and her incantations, the battle of Pharsalia, the Death of Pompey and the march of Cato through the Thessalian desarts with the various venomous reptiles that infest his army, are all full of horror, but many of them are disgusting. The author appears to have wanted taste to select his incidents of description. The imagination revolts from many of them, though all are striking. The Gods are treated very cavalierly. In the very outset he charges them with taking the wrong side in opposition to Cato. He afterwards says they never take offence at any crimes but those of the unfortunate, and he more than once apostrophises their injustice in suffering the crimes and success of Caesar. The. heroes are painted larger than life. The daring ambition of Caesar, the inflexible stoicism of Cato; and the declining greatness of Pompey, are well contrasted. The Egyptian characters are not so well drawn. Photinus is too bare-faced a villain. His policy might have been attributed to him without a departure from nature; but he should have been made more plausible.— On the whole my opinion not only of the translator but of the author has been raised by this perusal.— The address to Nero, is more extravagant but not more fulsome, than that of Virgil to Augustus, and must have been more excusable at the time when it was doubtless written, that is in the golden years of his reign. This is very evident from the complection of the whole poem: for certainly Lucan would not have ventured to publish the bold sentiments of Liberty that prevail in every part of it during the tyrannical part of the monster’s government. It is very probable however, that they cost the author his life. Though a mere rivalship, for Poetical fame is only mentioned by the historians as the cause from whence originated the conspiracy in which Lucan joined, and for which he suffered.

20. My brother went this morning for Utrecht, where the fair still continues. Mr: Du Roure called on me in the forenoon, at the request of Mr: Bonnechose, to ask me whether I could not give him, a stronger certificate as to his residence in America; told him I would with
pleasure if I could with propriety. It turns out that Bonnechose really assumed the name of Mouchon, for his particular purposes, and that when he told me the letters were not for him, he said what was not true.— Began to read the translation of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, as published by Garth. The first book is by Dryden. He calls the Palace of the Gods, the Louvre of the sky. and tells of Phaëton’s going to the Levé of his father Phoebus; as Rowe in one of Cato’s speeches makes him tell the soldiers they are fit only to pass as heir-looms from Pompey to Caesar.— Such expressions remind me of Anthony’s present to Cleopatra of a tompion gold watch, in Swift.— These Metamorphoses cannot well be included in my original plan of reading Epic Poets; but the variation will not be important and may serve to afford the relaxation of variety.— Began too this morning to read Tasso’s Jerusalem in the original, but I shall make very slow progress in that.— My two walks as usual.

21. Whitcomb extremely ill, and still more frightened in the night. Better this day.— Rather unwell myself. Walk with Mr: Levsen, whom I met just as I was going out. An hour this Evening at Mr: Dumas’s. The old gentleman disposes of the Cape of Good Hope, as the huntsman did of the bear’s skin before he had got the beast.— As I must sacrifice some of my occupations, I write and perform my Italian exercises now before breakfast, leaving my morning reading to the chance of leisure before dinner.— I fear it will be little, while I spend so much time upon two languages at once.

22. Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s. We read a few stanza’s of Tasso’s Jerusalem, and are charmd with the sweetness of the language. The invocation to the Muse is very beautiful, and has been imitated by Milton and by Voltaire.— Walk and literary conversation as usual in the wood. Find myself easier for the change of reading to writing in the morning before breakfast. But how rapidly time well employed flies away.— The second and third books of Garth’s Ovid are translated by Addison.

23. Received at length from Mr: Moliere, the money I had lent Mr: Pillet. The payment has hitherto been delayed by a mistake, or rather by a want of accuracy in arrangement, which was not sufficiently attended to at first. All is well however at present. Visit this afternoon from Mr: Dumas. He appears to be more accommodating than usual and was so the last time I saw him likewise. Walk in the evening. Overtaken by Bielfeld. Met Mr: Levsen, who told us of an English fleet to be seen at Scheveling.— We went there, and saw nothing. Indeed it was too dark; if there was any thing really to be seen.— Walk very pleasant.— The fourth book of the Metamorphoses translated by Eusden, except the story of Salmacis and Hermaphroditus which is by Addison. Has nothing remarkable.

24. Up at half past six. Owing perhaps to my Scheveling walk.— Lesson of Italian at Bielfeld’s at eleven, to accommodate him.— Walk alone—rainy. My brother returned this evening from Utrecht.— 5th: book of the Metamorphoses, translated by Arthur Maynwaring. Very indifferent. What sort of an heroic verse is

25. Visit this morning from Mr: Rutgers of New-York, who brought me a letter from my brother Charles, and a Mr: Roers. They went on immediately to Rotterdam, and are going to England. Gave me a New-York paper of June 15. Rutgers says there was some misunderstanding about the delivery of the Western Posts.— I have for some days past changed my morning reading to writing. I perform of course more writing but the reading suffers from it— Looked at the life of Agricola.— Reudorp’s Memoirs. Tasso’s Jerusalem.— And letters—and poetic reading, and miscellaneous reading.— My occupations are surely numerous enough.— 6th: Book of the Metamorphoses translated by Croxall. Much more harmonious than that of yesterday.

26. Letter this morning to Mr: Gore &c. Lesson of Italian at my lodgings. Began upon translating into that Language. Poor work of course.— Person brought me letter from Mr: Cathalan the V Consul of the U. States at Marseilles, recommending to me a couple of Algerines. My two walks. Met Mr. Levsen.

27. Mr: Macqueen (for so he spells his name to shew that he is not a Scotsman). was here. Went with him to look at the Count de Walderen’s furniture; to be sold next week. Does not suit me. My walks solitary. Do not meet Bielfeld so often as formerly.— Finished Pratt’s Gleanings, and his Poem of Humanity. The book is so large (3 Octavo Volumes) and contains so little that it put me out of humour several times. The perpetual repetition of the figure contained in his title is disgusting, and he should call himself a romantic rather than a residentiary traveller. He should have remembered that the barn of a gleaner should be proportioned to his character and employment. He appears ambitious to be thought an imitator of Yorick, and some of his sensibilities are not uninteresting. He must be content however in this walk with a station much below that of his master.— His accounts from Holland, whenever they relate to the Government of the Country are very inaccurate. He is right only in the most superficial details, which to be sure every traveller in this Country sees, but which very few travellers think it worth while to record. He frequently calls these Provinces the United States and talks of the Prince of Orange’s subjects. What can be the constitutional language knowledge of a man who knows no better than to use these expressions here? it must be very small, and accordingly Mr: Pratt discovers his ignorance in every page that he writes on this point.— His liberality is indeed laudable, not only as it is extraordinary for an Englishman, but as I think it in a great degree Dutch just. He carries it perhaps too far.— The Dutch are far from being the unfeeling People, which the arrogance and levity of travellers among them have represented; but neither are they the people of refined sensibility which Mr: Pratt seems disposed to allow them.— In spite of all he says I cannot reconcile myself to their language. It is founded neither on sentiment nor on science. It differs indeed very little from the English, but that difference is wholly to its disadvantage. The English have been for several centuries continually softening the teutonic gutturals and aspirates; they have been continually introducing french and Italian, as well as Roman and Greek derivatives.
The Excessive harshness of the Teutonic original language has been in some measure corrected by these practices. In the dutch classical language it subsists in all its horrors. Pratt observes that in the mouth of a pretty woman the Dutch often assumes a tone far from unpleasant. But he does not observe, what is in fact the case, that the pretty Dutch women, even in speaking their own language, use a vast number of words merely french, which the custom of female conversation has sanctioned among them, and has extended through all ranks of the sex, but which are seldom or ever used by the men, and are not to be found in any of the dictionaries or books of the language. Almost all the terms which naturally recur most frequently in common female discourse, are of this description, and enjoy this species of denization from the french into the Dutch language. This Author’s politics are like his other qualities superficial and momentary; and some of his opinions were refuted by Events before his book was published. Why burden the world with them?— I suppose after the trouble of writing, he could not afford to sacrifice them. A book must be made—and when the quantity was provided there was no haggling for the quality. The poem of Humanity, is in smooth verse, but contains only common place ideas.— Pratt is not an original thinker; but how few of these does the world produce.— It has a much greater defect. It is in two books; contains near two thousand verses and has no plan. It is altogether desultory slips alternately from one topic to another, and resumes the same again after having once taken it up.— It is likewise feeble, and deficient in the poetical fire the first and most essential characteristic of poetry. Those who can be satisfied with the well-tuned bells of rhyme, and the hot bed flowers of expression may read it with pleasure.

28. One of my eyes again very much inflamed. My Patience and my perseverance in the application upon which I have resolved, has no severer trial than this.— A physical incapacity makes resolution itself despair. And this is the third time that the affliction has renewed its visit, since I began upon the execution of my present plan. It has not yet affected it.— At the Dutch Play this Evening, where were performed Zoë, a translation from Mercier, a tragicomedy. & Eliza van Wallenthorst an original Dutch Farce, dull as the lakes that slumber in the storm. The Zoë is interesting, and, pathetic but unnatural. The moral is revolutionary, attacking the prejudices of aristocracy and the church. It holds up to horror the prejudice of attachment to rank, and the practice of shutting up women in a cloister. For this purpose all the licence of poetry and all the licentiousness of politics are used and abused, to produce a father such as the world never saw, for cruelty, a son and daughter equally distinguished for submission, and a catastrophe in which the father fires one pistol at his daughter’s lover, then deliberates for some time whether he shall fire another at him, or repent his former conduct and give his daughter away with a good grace, concludes upon the latter.— The performance was good Bingley as the father and Mademoiselle Wattier as Zoë, were really interesting. But Mr: Pratt in his gleanings is more than liberal to this Lady, when he places her upon a level with Mrs: Siddons, and he must have been as superficial a judge of the powers possess’d by Mrs: Siddons, as he appears to be of most other things to make the comparison.

29. Visit this morning from a Mr: Myndert van Heveren a native of New-York as he says all his ancestors to the great-grandfather have been, though he has such a dutchified name, that they sometimes take him for a counter-revolutionary. He came from England about a week ago. And wanted to return a passport to return. Went to introduce him into the Gallery of the Assembly, with a companion he had with him— Mr: Kempenaer is President. Debate not important.— Lesson of Italian. Walk afterwards with Bielfeld in the wood. Visit again in the afternoon from Mr: Pillet. Evening to see Madam Dumas. Gave her husband the Spanish and English Treaties urging to him strongly that there is nothing against the interest of France in the latter. He promised to make use of the argument.— Excused myself from a party at Mademoiselle Laurenzy’s, from the state of my eyes which is bad— My brother went.

30. Visit again this forenoon from Mr: Pillet. Who is going on to Paris.— Finished reading the Traité General de Commerce, a work from which I have derived some information. The second volume consists indeed principally of tables to be consulted occasionally, and over which I pass’d therefore in a cursory manner. The first contains an ample account of the Commerce of this Country to which of course my principal attention was paid.— Began reading the Lettres familieres et autres du Baron de Bielfeld; the father of my friend and fellow-student of Italian. find it amusing.

31. Curious letter this morning from Dr: Edwards, and one from Mr: Bourne— Visit this forenoon from Mr: Skinner, with another Gentleman from Boston. from Mr: Schermerhorn. In the afternoon from Mr: Heshuysen for a Passport. Lesson of Italian, and walk with Bielfeld in the wood.— These various avocations took almost the whole day from me.— I can never have a positive disposal of my time from half past eight in the morning. The preceding hours are on this account extremely valuable.— Weather very warm and feverish; it dissipates the animal spirits so as to take away the power of application.— Buffon was of opinion that Genius might be resolved into Patience.— If this idea be just I have very little genius in warm weather; especially in the sultry warmth of the dutch atmosphere. Began this morning upon Kerroux. Abregé de L’Histoire de la Hollande; but read only a very few pages in it.— Walk in the Voorhout in the Evening. Met Bielfeld, with a German Author; and Mr: Levsen. Walk’d sometime with the latter. I had enquired of him whether any application had been made by the friends of M. La Fayette to the Danish Court, to request its interference to obtain his liberation. He then told me he believed not. This Evening he told me he had written to the Comte de Bernstorff on the subject, and could now answer me for certain they had not. He could further add that La Fayette was now detained by the Emperor as a prisoner of the king of Prussia, and was kept under a promise made to him. That the Emigrants were at the bottom and his liberty could probably be obtained only by application from the king of Prussia, who would make it whenever the french Government may desire it. But that no other application would probably be successful. This short conversation of Levsen suggests many reflections to me and will deserve further meditation.

Day. July 1796. Rise at half past five, and set myself to reading or writing at six. continue till half past nine, when I go to breakfast. from thence till eleven read newspapers, and English Monthly or critical Reviews, and dress. from eleven till one, translate from the Dutch or Italian, or attend to visitors upon business or of complaisance. from one till half past two taking my Italian lesson at Bielfeld’s lodgings and my own alternately by weeks.— The days when we do not take a lesson, these hours are passed like the two immediately preceding. From half past two, one hour’s walk. from half past three to five, at dinner, and a little conversation after it. from five till dark, reading for amusement, a book of heroic English verse, and some miscellaneous prose. Another hour’s walk in the Evening. Supper at ten; bed at eleven. This course throughout the month has been regular with scarce a single exception. The greatest variation has been from the reading to writing in the morning before breakfast; and perhaps the present excess is that of writing too much, and reading not enough of the books of knowledge and importance.

The reading of the month has carried me through Luzac’s Richesse de la Hollande, and the Traité General de Commerce; the latter as mentioned on the day when I finished it. The life of Dumouriéz. Garat’s Memoires, and Pratt’s gleanings. Of all these books I have made mention and some slight observation at the time of finishing; and also of Pitt’s translation of the Eneid, Rowe’s Lucan, which I have gone through, and Garth’s compilation of the Metamorphoses which I have not yet finished. To improve in the Dutch language I have usually translated a page every day and after going thus through the Constitution of the National Assembly which is now in session, I took the Introduction to Reudorp’s Memoirs. I shall give the preference to all interesting state papers, because I send the translations to the Secretary of State, and thus answer two good purposes at once.— My progress in Italian is slow, and I can only translate two or three Stanza’s of Tasso at a time. the language itself is enchanting, but with no opportunity to speak or hear it spoken my advances are very small, and with my other occupations I may perhaps grow tired of that.— To keep alive my latin, I have begun to translate a page of Tacitus every day, and am going through the life of Agricola, which in the year 1784. at this place I translated into french. I find this author still new, and a special application to his writings will I hope be useful to me on several accounts. His language, his wisdom, his style, his method, all afford subject for meditation and improvement. This is not the part of my time the worst employed.— My other writing is principally confined to writing and answering letters, or to this journal. The time for original composition has not yet come; I know not whether it ever will. I shall probably never have a time so favorable for it as the present.— But I have no subject, and am far from being yet satisfied with my style.
